Name of Local Tribunal: New Quay District

Number of Case: 6

Name: Johnny Davies

Age: 23

Address: Vrondolay New Quay

Occupation, profession or business: General farm servant

Grounds: G. (His services are absolutely necessary for I am personally unable to do anything on the farm.)

Nature of application: I am asking for absolute Exemption.

Tag: Beige R41/42: Page 1

Reasons: I cannot manage my agricultural land without the services of Johnny Davies. If he is taken away I have no other alternative but to sell up my two horses and the two cows and allow the land to grow wild and to be uncultivated. As I asked before in my former application on Form R13 the aforesaid Johnny Davies and one housemaid are the only employees in my service. He is in full charge of the farm, doing anything necessary on it throughout the year. The horses, cows pigs and poultry are also under his sole care. He is also in charge of the garden. Including all I can assure you he is fully employed and his services are therefore absolutely necessary for me. I may add that I could not secure the services of anyone anywhere in the locality to replace him because of the scarcity of farm labour in the district and I therefore earnestly appeal for the exemption of the said Johnny Davies.

Signature: Jno[?] Thomas

Address: Vrondolay New Quay

Occupation, profession or business: gentleman

Date of application: 1916-02-15T18:03:18.000Z

Decision of the Tribunal: Appeal refused E.J. Davies Chairman March 14.1916

Tag: Beige R41/42: Page 2

Description: Form R-45. Notice of Appeal to Appeal (replacing form's "Central") Tribunal. Johnny Davies of Vrondolay New Quay, Farm Servant, not attested.

Transcription: I appeal on the grounds that I feel that my case has been unjustly considered by the Local Tribunal for reasons already submitted which are - 1. I hold 41 acres more or less of land, 26 acres of which are grazing land which I rent. 2. My arable land is about 4 or 5 acres more or less and to take my servant man away immediately will mean that this land will have to remain 12 months at least uncultivated, and so far I have NO prospects to secure any reliable farm hand to replace him. I cannot do anything myself - not brought up to it. 3. I have 2 horses, 2 colts the Carter are not in also 2 cows/calf and calf daily expected. It will not be easy to sell any of these at a moment's notice if my man is taken away immediately. My man is in sole charge of the above animals and of the farm. I asked for his exemption on the above grounds. If this is not justified from your point of view give me 2 months extension of time for me to set and sow the land or 6 weeks to dispense with or sell all of my animals and the land can remain in fallow.

Occupation, profession or business: Butcher & Farmer

Why appellant acts for the man: Because he is indispensable to me.

Date: 1916-05-12T11:23:53.000Z

Tag: Pink R43/R44: Page 1

Reason for decision of Local Tribunal: This application was disallowed by the Local Tribunal as in its opinion no case had been made out for exemption. The applicant states that he will have to give up his farm and his butcher's business if his son leaves, but he admitted in cross examination that he had been obliged to close his butcher's business all the winter owing to ill health, so that it cannot be contended that the business was in any way dependant on the extension of his son's services, and as for the farm the Tribunal felt that with the assistance of his two daughters who are at home he could easily look after his 20 acres of land even if his son who makes his living as a general labourer and only occasionally works for his father, has to join the forces. J.W. Thomas Clerk May 13th/16

Decision: Appeal dismissed by consent, the military representative agreeing that the man should not be called up for military service until the 15th day of July 1916. 2/6/16 John Jones Chairman

Transcription: To the Chairman and Members of the Appeal Tribunal for the County of Cardigan. Gentlemen, We the undersigned boatmen and fishermen earning our living in the Harbour of Newquay, respectfully appeal to the County Tribunal to uphold the decision of the Local Tribunal in the case of Mr Griffith Arthur Rees and to confirm his exemption. We are dependent on him for the supply of materials and for doing all repairs to our boats, and it is very important for us, that his services should be available as in the past. We would strongly emphasise the assertion that his retention in his foresent business is essential for us, and we consider his work is of national importance inasmuch as his service is important to us in fishing operations thus producing food for the Community We very earnestly appeal for his exemption, E. P. Jones. Lewis Davies, 14 Rock St; Daniel Davies, 10 Rock St; D E Jones, 4 Do; Evan Williams, 4 Rock St; R Williams, Thomas Davies, John Jones, Henry Davies, Evan Evans, Fred Charlor, Griffith Griffiths, David Evans, John Thomas, John Jones, David Rees, T. Description: Letter

Transcription: 9. On May 20th 1918 I was examined by the National Service Medical Board Carmarthen, and was handed a certificate of which the following is a Copy: "The examination of Mr Wm Williams residing at Brynsiloh, Nanternis, New Quay has been postponed till 20th July 1918 on account of T.B. on which date he will be required to present himself for Medical Examination." Signed: C.P.Parry, Deputy Commissioner Medical Board Carmarthen. Again on July 18th I was examined, and again received a Certificate similar to the above, postponing my examination till Sept 18th on account of T.B. I was the third time notified from Brecon to attend at Carmarthen for Examination on Sept 16th. On that date I was not examined by the Medical Board, and after about half-an-hour's search I was informed that my History Sheet had not been sent from Brecon, and was handed a "Classification Card" Grade (2), dated May 20th 1918, bearing in the space for Signature of Man , a signature other than mine. I objected to the date on the card, and to the signature, and then was allowed to sign that it was on Sept 16th that I received same. I was not allowed my day's fee (3/6d) at Carmarthen, as I was not examined, although a "Claim Form" was sent on to me from Brecon. In view of the above facts, I appeal for the right to appear before the Medical Assessors.

Description: Letter written by Evans Rowlands

Transcription: My name is Evan Rowlands now a butcher @ Aberayron and have 350 customers (350 coupons) per week to supply with meat, There are only two regular butchers at Aberayron. I joined the Army April 1916 And in three months training was discharged owing to a Valvular Disease of the Heart believing that I would not be called upon to join again I opened a business @ Aberayron. The Medical Gentlemen told me at my last examination, that I should not be sent for examination so often, owing to the fact that VDH will not improve by excitement E Rowlands
